Correspondences
William Archer Cocke to Robert E. Lee

odd.head: General
odd.p: William Archer Cocke wrote to Robert E. Lee February 1, 1866 from Monticello, Florida. He expresses the wishes of several youths in the Florida region to study at Washington College under Lee's leadership and requests a number of circulars on the college be sent to his address.

did.unittitle: Laura G. Ogle to Robert E. Lee

odd.head: General
odd.p: Laura G. Ogle wrote to Robert E. Lee from New Castle, Delaware on February 1, 1866. In the letter, she expressed her great admiration for Lee and her desire to emulate his example, despite societal pressures on her as a woman. She explains that her lifelong goal had become to meet and speak with Lee at some point. However, she explains that she has become and "invalid" and will remain so for her life, thus restricting herself to remaining in New Castle for the remainder of her life. She ends the letter with a request for a locke of Lee's hair.

did.unittitle: Ralph Lete to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ralph Lete wrote to Robert E. Lee on February 1, 1866 from Ironton, Ohio. He wrote to express his admiration for Lee, as well as to request a course catalog of Washington College for his son to potentially attend the school.

did.unittitle: Jones Bros. & Co. to Robert E. Lee

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Jones Bros. & Co. Subscription Book Publishers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this letter, Jones Bros. & Co. Subscription Book Publishers of Philadelphia, PA wrote a business letter to Robert E. Lee on February 2, 1866. In the letter, the company attempts to solicit their services to publish Lee's current writings on his Civil War Campaigns.

did.unittitle: J. Temple to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Temple of Richmond, Virginia to Robert E. Lee on February 2, 1866. In the letter, Temple requests that Lee send him a number of circulars on Washington College for those in the area of Richmond who are interested in attending.

did.unittitle: J. B. Williams to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. B. Williams of Enfield, North Carolina to Robert E. Lee. He wrote to request a set of course catalogs for Washington College, and explains that he is recommending the school to his students.

did.unittitle: W. W. Anderson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by W. W. Anderson of Bethany, West Virginia on February 2, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Anderson explains his dissatisfaction with the state of Bethany College. He requests that Lee, upon evaluation, accept himself and a dozen other Bethany College students into Washington College.

did.unittitle: Robert H. Patterson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Robert H. Patterson of Abingdon, Virginia on February 3, 1866. Patterson wrote to request Lee send to him a catalog of Washington College as well as the Law School.

did.unittitle: Joseph Finnegan to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Joseph Finnegan of Fenandina, Florida on February 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Finnegan explains to Lee that his friend, Captain Taylor, had recently passed away. He goes on to explain that Captain Taylor's two son's were currently attending Washington College. Finnegan continues to explain that the sons of Taylor are likely undisciplined due to their lack of quality education in their formative years. He requests that Lee offer them additional guidance in their situation.

did.unittitle: William Parker Snow to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Captain William Parker Snow of Nyack, New York on February 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Snow explains his intense admiration for Lee and his leadership. He explains that he is in the process of authoring a monograph on the subject of southern generals during the Civil War. He goes on to express his patriotism for the United States in its current form and his admiration of Lee's willingness to fight for what he believed in.

did.unittitle: C. B. Richardson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by C. B. Richardson of New York, NY on February 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Richardson expresses his company's interest in Lee's experiences, and mentions an included copy of a book on the "Army of the Potomac" for Lee to examine. Richardson also requests a photograph of General Pendleton be sent with Lee's response.

did.unittitle: M. Taylor to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by M. Taylor on February 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Taylor explains to Lee that a catalog previously requested of Lee did not arrive with its accompanying letter. Taylor goes on to explain that he sent his sons to Washington College without first knowing the requirements due to the missing catalog.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
H. B. Magruder to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by H. B. Magruder of Greensboro, Alabama on February 4, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter is written on behalf of the Southern University's branch of the Clariosophic Society to Lee, extending to him honorary membership based upon the merit of his actions during the Civil War.

did.unittitle: Virginia Railroad Company to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written on behalf of the Virginia Railroad Company in Richmond, Virginia on February 4, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter was written to Lee to inform him of a bill advocating the railroad's repair and to continue his support of the reconstruction of Virginia's infrastructure. The letter includes the bill itself, a printed prospectus, and assorted newspaper clippings referencing the project.

did.unittitle: R. L. Dabney to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by R. L. Dabney to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Dabney relayed that Lee's previous letter had been delivered to him safely. He goes on to thank Lee for his advice and describes ways in which he applied it.

did.unittitle: George J. Stewart to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by George J. Stewart of Madison Station, Virginia on February 5, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Stewart explains that he intends to apply to and attend Washington College for the coming semester. He also explains that he very much desired to attend the school where Lee was president, which led to a mistaken application to Virginia Military Institute where he initially believed Lee was president.

did.unittitle: Sam Beach Jones to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Sam Beach Jones of Bridgeton, New Jersey on February 5, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Jones relays that he his sending in tandem a copy of General Patterson's publication, which he would like Lee to look over and potentially give his permission to use Lee's name within.

did.unittitle: Charles Marshall to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Charles Marshall on February 5, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Marshall relays to Lee that his previous letter had been received, and that he is heeding Lee's advice as best he can.

did.unittitle: Rathmell Wilson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Rathwell Wilson in Philidelphia, Pennsylvania on February 6, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Wilson explains that he has recently inherited of a scientific library of books from his late brother, Thomas B. Wilson. He expresses his desire to donate a large portion it to various southern institutions of higher learning. He goes on to express his desire for Washington College to be one of the institutions to benefit from his donation. Included in the letter is a list of various monographs which Wilson sent to Washington College. Each title includes the number of volumes which were donated.

did.unittitle: C. H. Woodward to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Major C. H. Woodward of Rockbridge Baths, Virginia on February 6, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Woodward requests a loan from Lee, which he promises to repay in short order.

did.unittitle: J. W. Francis to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. W. Francis on February 6, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Francis explains to Lee that he has in his possession two documents that were taken from Lee's Arlington house during the Civil War by the army stationed on the Potomac. The documents mentioned include a deed dated 1632 and a work on the "Anti-Christian Conspiracy." Francis expresses his desire to return these items to Lee's possession at his earliest convenience.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Samuel H. Anderson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Samuel H. Anderson from Georgetown College in Washington, DC on February 8, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Anderson explains in the letter that the Philodemic Society of Georgetown College had elected to make Lee an honorary member.

did.unittitle: Lancaster & Co. to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by a representative of Lancaster & Co from Richmond, Virginia on February 9, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The company is informing Lee of a check from the treasurer of Ohio made out to Lee for $105 accrued in interest on bonds.

did.unittitle: Letter of Recommendation for John B. Mays to Robert E. Lee
G. W. Garmany to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by George Washignton Garmany from Savannah, Georgia on February 10, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Garmany wrote the letter as a recommendation for John B. Mays, a potential student of Washington College.

did.unittitle: Charles O. DeLahoussaye to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Charles O. DeLahoussaye in New Orleans, Louisiana on February 10, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, DeLahoussaye writes requesting that Lee send a catalog for Virginia Military Institute, as he desires to send his nephew to atttend school. DeLahoussaye potentially erroneously ascertained that Lee was the president of VMI.

did.unittitle: M. A. Gibbs to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by M. A. Gibbs from Vicksburg, Mississippi on February 10, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. He requests in the letter that Lee admit his son into Washington College.

did.unittitle: Sam Tyler to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Sam Tyler from Frederick City, Maryland on February 12, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Tyler informs Lee that Prof. Baer intends to have a collection of minerals identified and labeled within several months for the use of Washington College.

did.unittitle: L. Davis to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by L. Davis from Prospect Hill, Georgia on February 12, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Davis relays to Lee that he had heard a speech on history recounting the evacuation of Richmond by Jefferson Davis, and transcribed a section he believed would be of interest to Lee, which is also included with the letter.

did.unittitle: W. M. Black to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by W. M. Black from Lynchburg, Virginia on February 13, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Black explains to Lee that a package has been recovered at his Southern Express Company office that contains cash addressed to Lee. He requests that Lee respond with instructions on what to do with the package.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
John R. Glascock to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by John Raglan Glascock from the University of Virginia on February 14, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Glascock requests that a catalog or circular for Washington College be forwarded to him at the request of a friend from California interested in attending.

did.unittitle: J. B. Heck to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. B. Heck on February 14, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter acts as a bill and statement of service to Washington College. Heck states the materials needed and the requested services for building shelving for the Washington College Library.

did.unittitle: J. P. Branch to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. P. Branch from Augusta, Georgia on February 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Branch expresses his admiration for Lee and requests an autograph be sent to him.

did.unittitle: L. Jervey to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by L. Jervey from Charleston, South Carolina on February 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Jervey informed Lee of a bulk of cotton in his possession that he wishes to give to Lee. He goes on to praise him for his character and actions during the war.

did.unittitle: A. B. Robertson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by A. B. Robertson from New Wartrace, Tennessee on February 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Robertson requests Lee to send him a circular on Washington College. He goes on to explain his motivations in doing so.

did.unittitle: E. F. Farrar and Annie De Moss to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Mrs. E. F. Farrar and Annie De Moss from Vicksburg, Mississippi on February 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The two women write that their letter includes a check for $536 intended for Stonewall Jackson's widow and child, and request that Lee forward it at his convenience. The letter continues and expresses the pain that is felt by them in defeat after the war's end, and describe the nature with which life continues in the south. They express their admiration for both Jackson and Lee, and describe the reverence with which their names are held in their households.

controlaccess.geogname: United States -- Confederate States of America

did.unittitle: A. S. Buford to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by A. S. Buford from Richmond, Virginia on February 16, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Buford writes from Richmond as president of the Richmond & Danville Rail Road, and presents to Lee tickets for use on the railroad. He concludes by requesting an autograph from Lee.

did.unittitle: William P. Marlin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by William P. Marlin on February 16, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Marlin writes to request that Lee send to his address a circular for Washington College for his son, a prospective student.

did.unittitle: Burke, Herbert & Co. to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Burk, Herbert & Co. from Alexandria, Virginia on February 17, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The company is writing to inform Lee that $25 have been added to the account of Sydney Smith Lee.

did.unittitle: J. Warner to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Warner from Washington, D.C. on February 17, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Warner writes to Lee to inform that he had come across an individual in Philadelphia in possession of a scrapbook of material relating to the Washington family. Warner requests that Lee relay any knowledge which could be used to return the scrapbook to its rightful owner.

did.unittitle: George, Count Joannes to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by George, Count Joannes from New York City on February 17, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, he expresses his admiration of Lee and his displeasure with the established concepts of Reconstruction and of the "radical cloud" rising from Congress. He makes mention of his public letters which have been published in the New York News. He goes on to say that when he next visits Virginia that he will donate to Washington College a portion of his profits.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
N. B. Feagin to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by N. B. Feagin from Midway, Alabama on February 18, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Fiegan requests Lee send to him a Washington College circular due to his interest in attending.

did.unittitle: M. S. Clarke to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by M. S. Clarke from Louisville, Kentucky on February 19, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Clarke requsts a set of catalogs for himself and several other young men in his area, as they are interesting in attending Washington College.

did.unittitle: Henry B. Dawson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Henry B. Dawson from Morrisania, New York on February 18, 1866. In the letter, Dawson expresses his interest in Lee's efforts to publish his father's memoirs. Dawson offers his assistance as an historian, and includes a segment of The Historical Magazine highlighting his past historical work.

did.unittitle: C. R. Hubbard to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by C. R. Hubbard from Montgomery, Alabama on February 20, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Hubbard asks Lee to send to him a catalogue of classes at Washington College, as well to write back any information that would ensure his admission to the college.

did.unittitle: Frank Magruder to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Frank Magruder from Goshen, Kentucky on February 20, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Magruder requests that Lee send to him a circular for Washington College, as his son is interested in attending the school.

did.unittitle: D. S. Mulee to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by D. S. Mulee from Fort Pulaski, Georgia on February 20, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Mulee writes from the fort prison, vouching for the character of his friend, John M. Taylor's, sons who had been sent to attend school at Washington College.

did.unittitle: Charles E. Waters to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Charles E. Waters from Baltimore, Maryland on February 21, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Waters describes how the ladies of Baltimore are organizing a fair to raise funds for the relief of southerners affected bt the Civil War. He requests, at the suggestion of his wife, that Lee send a set of his autographs to be sold at the fair to raise money for their cause.

did.unittitle: Robert E. Lee Jr. to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter is written by Robert E. Lee Jr. on February 19, 1866 to his father, Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Robert E. Lee Jr. expresses to his father that he was happy to hear from him and his mother recently. He goes on to ask advice from his father regarding the mill he now operates. He explains the situation of some mechanical problems witht he mill and dam, and asks his father to provide advice on the course of action to take and how to apply the repairs effectively.

did.unittitle: J. Lawrence Saulsbury to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was writen by J. Lawrence Saulsbury from Richmond, Virginia on February 20, 1866. Saulsbury begins the letter by expressing his admiration for Lee and his wish to meet him in person. He then transitions into encouraging Lee to allow the company he represents, Blakeney & Co., to supply Washington College's students with sets of gold pens at the cost of $1 each.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
W. P. Moore to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by W. P. Moore from Palmyra, Missouri on February 22, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Moore requests a response from Lee on the question of to whom he needed to seek the copyright of Lee's historical exploits during the war while in Missouri.

did.unittitle: Laura G. Ogle to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Laura G. Ogle from New Castle, Delaware on February 23, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter is a follow up to a previous response given by Lee. Ogle expresses her gratitude for Lee's fulfillment of her reqeust of a signed photograph.

did.unittitle: Maj. George L. Gillespie, Jr. to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by former CSA Staff member of General Stevenson, Major George L. Gillespie from Chatanooga, Tennessee on February 24, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Gillespie writes the letter as an introduction to two relatives of his attending Washington College, Robert N. and Thomas J. Gillespie. He vouches for their quality of character and hopes Lee will provide them with a role model.

did.unittitle: Philologic Society to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Horace Sheley on behalf of the Philologic Society of Westminster College on February 24, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter extends an invitation for Lee to become and honorary member of the Philologic Society.

did.unittitle: William H. Botts to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by William H. Botts from Glasgow, Kentucky on February 26, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Botts writes to introduce Buford Leslie to Lee and vouch for his character while he attends Washignton College.

did.unittitle: William Brazelton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by William Brazelton from New Market, Tennessee on February 25, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Brazelton writes as a way to introduce J. M. Gillespie from Rhea County who attended Washington College. He also explains some events of his life, as well as the nature of young southern men.

did.unittitle: Butler, Perrigo, and Way to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written on behalf of the company of art-dealers Butler, Perrigo, and Way from Baltimore, Maryland on February 26, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The dealers express their thanks to Lee for sending them a series of autographs they had previously requested. They inform Lee that the autographs are to be framed and sold by their dealership.

did.unittitle: D. Creel to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by D. Creel from Chillicothe, Ohio on February 24, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter begins by praising Lee and making several biblical comparisons to Lee. Creel continues and begins to refer to his relation to Stonewall Jackson by marriage, and begins to recount events of Jackson's life as he viewed them up until his death during the Civil War. Creel also describes events of his own life, including raids by northern militias on his home.

did.unittitle: Jones Bros. & Co. to Robert E. Lee

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Jones Bros. & Co. Subscription Book Publishers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written on behalf of Jones Bros. & Co. from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on February 26, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The company writes to follow up on Lee's rejection of the previous offer for the company to publish his personal works. The follow up resolves with an open offer should Lee change his mind.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Demosthenian Society to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written on behalf of the Demosthenian Society from the University of Georgia in Athens, Georgia on February 27, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The Demosthenian Society writes to inform Lee that he has been made an honorary member based upon his reputation and actions.

did.unittitle: J. Johns to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Bishop J. Johns on February 27, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Johns writes from Theological Seminary to inform Lee of the death of "Bishop Meade."

did.unittitle: Demosthenian Society of Roanoke to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written on behalf of the Demosthenian Society of Roanoke College from Salem, Virginia on February 28, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The society writes to inform Lee that he has been elected to be an honorary member of the society.

did.unittitle: Cordes Sisters to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by the Cordes Sisters and their personal friend Mary Byrnes from Ridgevill, South Carolina on February 27, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter was sent in care of the sisters' father, Captain Theodore Cordes from Charleston, South Carolina. The letter is a follow up to a previous request of the sisters that went unanswered from December of 1865. The sisters requested some small memento from Lee, as they had great respect for him.

did.unittitle: Maria G. Slaughter to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Mary G. Slaughter on February 27, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Slaughter writes to introduce Stark Arnold to Lee as the nephew of Stonewall Jackson. She vouches for his integrity and explains his situation of desiring an education without direct means. She requests that Lee assist him in gaining an education.

did.unittitle: George W. Leyburn to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by G. W. Leyburn from Big Lick, Virginia on February 27, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Leyburn makes reference to a previous conversation he and Lee had regarding the nature of education. He expands on this topic and asks a series of questions regarding education in the South and requests a written response to the questions. He explains that he wishes to have Lee's stance while Leyburn acts to acquire subscriptions for Washington College's endowment.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
M. B. Smith to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Mrs. M. B. Smith from Port Royal, Virginia on March 1, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Smith informs Lee that she wishes for her son to attend Washington College. She requests Lee for a school catalogue.

did.unittitle: J. M. Handely to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. M. Handely on March 1, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Handely requests a copy of Lee's ongoing work on the history of the "Great Rebellion."

did.unittitle: Edward A. Pollard to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter and attached news clippings were written by Edward A. Pollard from Norfolk, Virginia on March 2, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Pollard explains, in reference to a previous correspondence, that he has become aware of an individual who has published his own scholarly work on the Civil War called "The Lost Cause" in the newspaper The New York News and is seeking action. He sent the letter attached with two clippings from papers in which Pollard directly addresses the culprit and publicly denounces his actions of infringement.

did.unittitle: Great Southern & Western Accident & Life Insurance Co. to Robert E. Lee

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Great Southern & Western Accident & Life Insurance Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written on behalf of the Great Southern & Western Accident & Life Insurace Company of New Orleans, Louisiana on March 2, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The company writes to inform Lee that he has been elected one of five members of the Non-Resident Board of stockholders.

did.unittitle: W. S. Neal to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by W. S. Neal on behalf of the Jefferson Davis Society of the Stonewall Institute from Perry County, Alabama on March 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter explains the society's purpose and goals, while praising southern ideals. It then invites and requests Lee to become a member of the society.

controlaccess.corpname: Stonewall Institute of Perry County, Alabama

did.unittitle: J. Longstreet to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Longstreet from New Orleans, Louisiana on March 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Longstreet writes to Lee informing him that he has inserted Lee's name as a one of the non-resident board of directors for the Great Southern and Western Life and Accident Insurance Company. He gives description of the company and its then-current assets. Included with the letter is a typed transcript.

controlaccess.corpname: Great Southern & Western Accident & Life Insurance Co.

did.unittitle: J. Johns Jr. Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Johns Jr. from Richmond, Virginia on March 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Johns writes to Lee that his letter accompanies another letter from Dr. Julius Doetsh. He explains that, upon his advice, Doetsh wishes to make a translation of Lee's work. He then vouches for Doetsh's credentials and character.

did.unittitle: Dr. Julius Edmund Doetsh to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Dr. Julius Edmund Doetsh from Richmond, Virginia on March 3, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Doetsh introduces himself to Lee and makes an offer to translate Lee's in-progress memoirs into German for European publication. He explains that interest in Europe is high for such a publication, and explains the potential avenues for publication which he can take advantage of.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
W. H. McGuire to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by W. H. McGuire from Washington, DC on March 4, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In her letter, McGuire relays to Lee her thanks for his assistance and relaying of the news of her husband's death.

did.unittitle: Thomas H. Ellis to Robert E. Lee

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: James River and Kanawha Company (Richmond, Va.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Thomas H. Ellis from Richmond, Virginia on March 6, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Ellis writes to inform Lee that the company's general assembly has voted to move forward with granting a French company an amended charter with contents that had been requested by the French company. He goes on to express his unease at working with the French, given bad relations and lack of resources following the Civil War. He then requests Lee write to him his opinions on the topics of the canal project, as well as peace relations abroad.

did.unittitle: J. Speer Howarth to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Speer Howarth from Delaware County, Pennsylvania on March 6, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Howarth requests information on Washington College pertaining to its student population and the general atmosphere of the college.

did.unittitle: J. Emanuel to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Emanuel on March 7, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Emanuel expresses interest in sending his son to Washington College and requests information on admission.

did.unittitle: George M. Branner to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by George Michael Branner from Knoxville, Tennessee on March 7, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Branner writes the letter as an introduction to his son Hardy Bryan Branner and his friend Rudolph Bryan. He vouches for their character, and explains that all funds for their education are accommodated.

did.unittitle: E. C. Middleton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by E. C. Middleton from Washington, DC on March 7, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Middleton introduces his agent, E. F. Lutz of Baltimore. Middleton then explains that his previous request of an oil painting of Lee had been rejected due to a lack of one existing. Middleton explains that Lutz will take notes of Lee's complexion and then, using a recent photograph by Mathew Brady, create an oil painting which he wishes Lee to sign.

did.unittitle: J. W. Lapsley to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by John W. Lapsley from Shelby County, Alabama on March 7, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. He writes to Lee introducing his son, John B. Lapsley who is attending Washington College. He goes into deep detail about his son's mannerisms and behavior, expressing hope that Lee's leadership will help to mold him appropriately.

did.unittitle: Benjamin B. Stith to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Benjamin B. Stith from Bewleyville, Kentucky on March 7, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Stith writes that he wishes to send his son to a military academy, believing Lee to be the president of VMI. He asks Lee to send him information and his favor in accepting his son into the school.

did.unittitle: Thomas E. McNeill to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Thomas E. McNeill from Lynchburg, Virginia on March 8, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. McNeill writes to share with Lee the mission of the newly-formed Virginia Mining and Manufacturing Bureau. He asks Lee for his support and includes an attached circular pertaining to the organization.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
W. W. Early to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by William W. Early from Hyattsville, Maryland on March 9, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Early requests from Lee a catalogue of classes for Washington College.

did.unittitle: N. S. Ray to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by N. S. Ray from Lebanon, Kentucky on March 9, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Ray asks in the letter for a catalogue of studies, as well as general information for Washington College. Ray explains that his son wishes to transfer from Centre College in Kentucky to Washington College.

did.unittitle: William Hunter to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by William Hunter from Savannah, Georgia on March 9, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Hunter writes to Lee informing him that his three sons wish to attend Washington College. He describes the natures of his sons as well as their academic potential.

did.unittitle: John Brown Baldwin to Robert E. Lee
E. L. Hadden to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Ths letter was written by E. L. Hadden from New York City on March 10, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Hadden writes to Lee informing him that he is returning to Lee a series of items recovered from the occupation of Arlington House at the onset of the Civil War.

did.unittitle: J. L. Hocker to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. L. Hocker on behalf of the Periclean Society of the University of Kentucky in Lexington, Kentucky on March 10, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter is written to inform Lee that he has been elected as an honorary member of the society.

did.unittitle: C. Newton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by C. Newton from Louisiana State Seminary (later Louisiana State University) on March 10, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. The letter is written to inform Lee that a society has been formed at the school named the Lee Society, and that Lee has been elected an honorary member.

did.unittitle: Francis H. Smith to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by VMI Superintendent Francis H. Smith on March 12, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Smith writes to inform Lee that a new VMI cadet, William F. Dancey, believes that the damage to VMI has resulted in the institution being unable to perform its purpose. He relays Dancey's desire to instead enroll in Washington College.

did.unittitle: Sam Barnett to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Sam Barnett from Washington, Georgia on March 12, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Barnett writes to Lee informing him that his ward, William H. Barnett, wishes to attended Washington College.

did.unittitle: Rathmell Wilson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Rathmell Wilson from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania on March 12, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Wilson writes the letter as a follow up to his previous correspondence with Lee regarding the donation of Thomas B. Wilson's library to Washington College. Wilson inquires whether the boxes of books arrived as planned. He also indicates that he wishes to donate further books in his possession to Washington College on the stipulation that the donated books be cared for, retain Thomas Wilson's book plate, and be called "the Wilson contribution to the Library of Washington College." Wilson additionally indicates that he has included a copy of Thomas Wilson's memoir in the donation.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Lt. von Clausewitz to Robert E. Lee
J. Marshall Dent to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by J. Marshall Dent from Maryland Agricultural College on March 13, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Dent explains to Lee that the classes at Maryland Agricultural College are to be suspended by March 25. He requests information on Washington College and inquires of the possibility of enrolling late in the term.

did.unittitle: C. G. Freuman to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by C. G. Freuman from Eminence, Kentucky on March 13, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Freuman requests that Lee send him a catalog for the "military institute" which Lee is head of, mistakenly assuming Lee is the head of Virginia Military Institute also in Lexington, VA.

did.unittitle: William H. Kinnon to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by William H. Kinnon from Tangipaho Station, Lousiana on March 13, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Kinnon writes to request information on costs of attendance for the sons of his five sisters.

did.unittitle: C. B. Richardson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by C. B. Richardson from New York City on March 13, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Richardson thanks Lee for his previous correspondence and expresses interest in sending Lee a series of documents and books to assist him.

did.unittitle: S. D. Stuart to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by S. D. Stuart from Baltimore, Maryland on March 14, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Stuart writes on behalf of Mrs. James Robb, asking for a likeness of Lee, whom she greatly admires.

did.unittitle: George William Green to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by George William Green from Shieldfield , Newcastle on Tyne, England.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
W. Scott Glore to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by W. Scott Glore from Louisville, Kentucky on March 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Glore offers to pay for $1000 of the publication costs of Lee's in-progress written histories of his campaigns during the Civil War.

did.unittitle: P. T. Moore to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by P. T. Moore from Richmond, Virginia on March 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. In the letter, Moore explains that his friend from the British Parliament has requested an autographed photograph. Moore also explains that his other friend, Dr. Thomas Antisell, inquires about a potential agriculture or geology position at Washington College.

did.unittitle: Emma Willard to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by American educator Emma Willard on March 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. Willard introduces herself and explains that she is a writer of history and has followed Lee's career through the war. She expresses her wish to establish contact with various generals, including Lee, to record their views of experiences for an upcoming school history book on the topic.

did.unittitle: American Publishing Company to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by S. S. Scranton and J. B. Burr from the American Publishing Company from Hartford, Connecticut on March 15, 1866 to Robert E. Lee. They write to inquire on Lee's status in writing his history of the war, and continue to express interest in negotiating a publishing contract.

did.unittitle: J. A. G. Williamson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter informs Robert E. Lee of his honorary membership to the Jackson Society, a literary society at the College of William and Mary. This was written by J. A. G. Williamson, the secretary of the society. The reverse shows that Robert E. Lee answered the letter on March 23rd, 1866.

did.unittitle: Meade Woodson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Meade Woodson of Fincastle, Botetourt County, VA. Woodson writes to Lee on behalf of a Ms. Hamilton who is considering sending her two sons to the institution. She wonders if there will military training at Washington College and if there's boarding for students available with Christian professors.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
William C. Folkes to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a letter from William C. Folkes to Robert E. Lee. He has sent a list of Battle Reports from the Confederate States of America (CSA). Along with the letter is a yellow piece of paper listing the battles recognized by the CSA.

did.unittitle: Fanny Bain to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was sent to Robert E. Lee from "Fanny" Bain, a corresponding secretary of the Eunomian Literary Society. The society offers Lee honorary membership if he would send a letter of acceptance and make a contribution to the Literary Gems paper.

did.unittitle: Thomas T. Munford to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Thomas Munford for Robert E. Lee. HAving learned that R. E. Lee is planning to write a war memoir, Munford writes to Lee to correct information within the offical Confederate report of the cavalry battle at Aldie, Virginia in 1863.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Correspondences
Abner Johnson Leavenworth to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Reverend Abner Johnson Leavenworth, writing as secretary of the Teachers' Association of Virginia. He asks Lee to address the organization's anniversary meeting in July 1866 about acceptance and education of Virginia's formerly enslaved people. Lee noted on the reverse of the Letter that he declined the invitation to speak.

did.unittitle: Charles W. Cole to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Charles W. Cole. Originally this letter was given to Lee with two books, "Rollin's Belles Lettres" and "The Letters of Cicero" that came from his home in Arlington. This letter is an explanation for how Cole obtained them and why he is giving them back.

controlaccess.geogname: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial (Va.)
controlaccess.subject: Rollin's Belles Lettres
The Letters of Cicero
controlaccess.corpname: United States. Army. Ohio Infantry Regiment, 145th (1864)

did.unittitle: John W. Fiwell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from John W. Fiwell. Fiwell asks for a circular of Washington College. Fiwell also mentions he is a wounded soldier from Company A of the Fourth Virginia Cavalry.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army. Virginia Cavalry Regiment, 4th

did.unittitle: R. G. Williams to Robert E. Lee
Edward Long Hedden to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Edward Long Hedden. Hedden tells Lee he has received the engraving of Washington and gives his thanks.

did.unittitle: S. J. Henderson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from S. J. Henderson. Henderson and Judge Charles Lewis McConnell have heard Lee plans to write a book on the American Civil War. Henderson and McConnell ask to have publishing agency in Kentucky for Lee's book.

controlaccess.subject: Publishers and publishing
controlaccess.corpname: Big Sandy Coal, Oil and Mining Company

did.unittitle: Sargent, Wilson & Hinkle to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from the book publisher Sargent, Wilson and Hinkle. This letter asks Lee for his approval of McGuffey Eclectic Readers books on the American Civil War.

controlaccess.genreform: McGuffey's first-sixth eclectic reader (McGuffey, William Holmes)

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Wilmer McLean to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Wilmer McLean. McLean asks Lee if he would come back to Appamatox to have a photograph of him taken in the room where he surrendered to General Ulysses S. Grant a year before.

did.unittitle: Ellen Reily to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Ellen Reily. She asks Lee if he could include her husband in his book on the American Civil War. She includes newspaper clippings, orders, and letters by and about her husband Colonel James Reily.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army. Sibley Brigade

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Elizabeth Hull to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Elizabeth (referred to as Lizzie in the letter) Hull. She asks for information about Washington College for her adopted child.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Algernon Sidney Vigus to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Algernon Sidney Vigus. Vigus has acquired Lee family letters that were taken from his home in Arlington, VA. He would like to give them back and asks how he would like them presented. One of the letters, to a Custis family member from London in 1728, is mentioned specifically. Vigus wishes to keep the letter if not important to Lee. Lee received all of the letters and mailed back the one from 1728.

controlaccess.geogname: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial (Va.)

did.unittitle: H. McLeavy to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from H. McLeavy. McLeavy, a third-year of Soule University, wishes to attend Washington College for his fourth year. He also states that he served in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War and some of the classes he has taken.

did.unittitle: Hezekiah George David Brown to Robert E. Lee

origination.label: Creator
origination.persname: Brown, Hezekiah George David (H. G. D.), 1824-1877

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Hezekiah George David (H. G. D.) Brown. Brown wishes to send his son to Washington College. He states that his son served in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War and was paroled in Alabama.

did.unittitle: Charles Wesley Andrews to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Charles Wesley Andrews. Andrews contacts Lee for a few different reasons. The first is a life update that his wife, Sarah, died in 1863. He then asks for two photographs of Lee with his autograph, one of them for his daughter. Andrews also enclosed a pamphlet that he recently published. Finally he asks for Lee to tell his wife Mary that her cousin Anny's husband has made $90.00 in the past year.

did.unittitle: Thomas L. Brown to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Thomas L. Brown. This letter accompanied a report by Brown of the Coal River Navigation Company which he hopes will take interest in minerals found in Virginia.

did.unittitle: Benjamin S. Elliott to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Benjamin S. Elliott. Elliott wishes to give Lee a Colt of the horse Patrick Henry. Included with this letter is a Carte de visite of Patrick Henry.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For Benjamin S. Elliott's later correspondence with Lee, see his letter from April 27, 1866 in Folder 56.

did.unittitle: Rev. Robert S. Clark to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Reverend Robert S. Clark. Clark asks for the rights to publish Lee's history of the American Civil War in different counties of Mississippi.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi Infantry Regiment, 30th

did.unittitle: William H. Hope to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from William H. Hope. Hope, a land lawyer in Virginia, wishes to represent Lee in gaining his Arlington estate back. He includes a newspaper clipping that union bodies will be dug from battlefields of the American Civil War and placed in Arlington.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See the letter from Hope dated March 22nd, 1866 in folder 49.

controlaccess.geogname: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial (Va.)
controlaccess.subject: Clippings (Books, newspapers, etc.)

did.unittitle: Charles B. Richardson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Charles B. Richardson. Richardson plans to donate $1,000 in books to the library of Washington College. He also says he will publish Lee's father's memoir once the family portraits arrive for engraving.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: See Charles B. Richardson's earlier letter to Robert E. Lee written March 20th, 1866 in folder 49.

did.unittitle: Alexander Gardner to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Alexander Gardner. A portion of Gardner's Carte de visite photographs did not arrive to Lee. To make up for this, Gardner is sending photographs that are on hand at the studio with his imprint. He also plans to make and mount one-hundred photographs without his imprint.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Lemuel Parker Conner to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Lemuel Parker Conner. Conner is giving this letter to Robert E. Lee through his nephew William C. Conner, introducing him to Lee.

did.unittitle: John O. Sullivan to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John O. Sullivan asks Lee for catalogues of Washington College for some of his students who wish to attend.

did.unittitle: S. P. Cunningham to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: S. P. Cunningham wants to obtain Washington College catalogues for Fairview Academy students wanting to attend.

did.unittitle: Warren Newcomb to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newcomb, after making a donation to Washington College, clarifies that he was born in Massachussetts, not in the south and requests a photograph of Lee.

did.unittitle: William Andrew Quarles to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from William Andrew Quarles. Quarles wishes to send his son to Washington College and asks for a catalog. He notes that his son is in Canada but made his way to Lieutenant in the Confederate Army during the American Civil War.

did.unittitle: Edward Payson Walton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Edward Payson Walton. Walton has been informed by Carter James Harris, professor of latin at Washington College, that Lee has taken offense to rumours published by Walton. Walton writes to Lee as an apology for any misunderstandings.

did.unittitle: James Kerr Caskie to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from James Kerr Caskie. Caskie thanks Lee for his favors sent on the 7th and the 10th of Aprill 1866. Caskie is glad to hear that the vase and chair that he has sent are cherished. Caskie also tells Lee that his sister Agnes will be visiting Lexington, accompanied by Lee's son William Henry Fitzhugh Lee. On the other side of this letter is a balance of items bought. Caskie notes that he received 2 dozen photographs of Lee from Julian Vannerson but Vannerson would not accept money.

did.unittitle: Martin Luther Smith to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from Martin Luther Smith. Smith writes to Lee after hearing that Washington College will be setting up a program for engineering. He asks if this school will be separate or a department and what books will be used.

did.unittitle: E. H. Campbell to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from E. H. Campbell, cordial secretary for the Charles Town Christian Association. Campbell informs Lee that he has been made an honorary member.

did.unittitle: Clara Banks to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Clara Banks of Liverpool, England. She writes to him asking for his autograph. Above the letter is her monogram which takes influence from illuminated manuscript lettering.

did.unittitle: Daniel Moreau Barringer to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Daniel Moreau Barringer. Barringer wishes to send his son Lewin to Washington College and is asking for a catalogue. He writes from Baltimore but instructs Lee that he lives in Raleigh, North Carolina.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
J. L. Greer to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from J. L. Greer who wishes to send his brother to Washington College for his junior year. He asks for a catalogue so his brother can properly prepare.

did.unittitle: Oden Bowie to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Oden Bowie, Governor of Maryland. He asks Lee to send a catalogue for an aquaintance that wants to send someone to Washington College.

did.unittitle: James Woods Smith to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee is from James Woods Smith. Smith plans to attend Washington College and asks for a catalogue and additional information to attend.

did.unittitle: S. D. Rosan to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from S. D. Rosan. Rosan wishes to attend Washington College and asks for Lee to send a circular of the school.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth S. Myrick to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Elizabeth S. Myrick (writing as Mrs. S. P. Myrick). Elizabeth wishes to send her son, James, to Washington College and asks for a circular and requirements to attend. She explains that her son left school at fifteen to serve in the Civil War and fears his age and limited schooling before the war may hinder his opportunity to the school.

did.unittitle: Henry A. Barling to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Henry A. Barling. Barling wishes for his nephew to attend Washington College and asks for a circular. He says his nephew has grown up in Georgia until late in the war and is currently attending school in Troy, New York. He also says that while his nephew is only fifteen he is very advanced in his studies.

did.unittitle: John Reynolds Winston to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from John Reynolds Winston. Winston asks if Lee is writing a history of the American Civil War and urges him to do so.

did.unittitle: John E. Matthews to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Matthews explains that he left school during the Civil War to serve in the Confederate Army. To make up for loss time he wishes to attend Washington College. Matthews asks Lee for a circular and requirements to attend.

did.unittitle: Henry F. Mayer to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mayer requests information on Washington College as he wishes to send his son to the school.

did.unittitle: James A. Mitchell to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from James A. Mitchell. Mitchell is interested in attending Washington College and would like catalogues sent for him and other potential students in Edmonton, Kentucky.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
John Hough James to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from John Hough James. James informs Lee that if he wishes to keep receiving the Urbana Union newspaper, he can resend the envelope this letter was enclosed in. If Lee does not wish to keep receiving this paper, he should send it back with a cross next to his name.

did.unittitle: George Lyttleton Peyton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from George Lyttleton Peyton. Peyton offers for Lee to come stay at the hotel.

did.unittitle: S. S. Louisa to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from S. S. Louisa Cochrane. Cochrane hopes to send her son William G. "Gilly" Cochrane to Washington College and requests a catalogue or circular.

did.unittitle: Dominick James Dillon to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter is addressed to Robert E. Lee from Dominick James Dillon.Dillon wishes to send his son to Washington College and is awaiting a catalogue.

did.unittitle: Benjamin S. Elliott to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter to Robert E. Lee comes from Benjamin S. Elliott. Elliott informs Lee that he favor he asked for on the 24th of April, 1866 has been fulfilled. Although Lee did not accept Elliott's offer for Patrick Henry's colt, Elliott is negotating for a two-year-old colt to be given to Lee. This letter also contains its original envelope.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For Benjamin S. Elliott's earlier correspondence with Lee, see his letter from April 10, 1866 in Folder 53.

did.unittitle: Unsigned note to Lee dated April 28th, 1866

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This note came with a package addressed to Robert E. Lee. The note explains a forwarded package meant for Lee from Algernon Sidney Vigus. The package contained books Vigus removed from the Lee family's "Arlington House" during the American Civil War.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: For context of this note, see Algernon Sidney Vigus' original letter to Lee dated April 9th, 1866 in folder 53.

controlaccess.geogname: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial (Va.)

did.unittitle: Walter Hanson Jenifer to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter was written by Walter Hanson Jenifer to Robert E. Lee. Jenifer writes that he has decided to retire from cavalry service and is now part of a business. He offers his services to Lee if he ever needs them. Included with this letter is an advertisement for Jenifer's business, "Jenifer and Brother".

controlaccess.subject: Cavalry
controlaccess.corpname: Jenifer & Brother General Purchasing and Sale Agency
Confederate States of America. Army. Virginia Cavalry Regiment, 8th

did.unittitle: Chestley Netterville to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter is written by Chestley Netterville to Robert E. Lee. Netterville wishes to attend Washington College in the fall of 1866 and would like a catalogue.

did.unittitle: John C. Breckinridge to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by John Cabell Breckinridge is to Robert E. Lee. Breckinridge asks for Lee to keep an eye and advise three brothers, William, James, and Edward Carson, attending Washington College. He also has heard that Lee is planning to write about the American Civil War campaigns in Virginia but that he has little written material to share.

did.unittitle: S. G. Landes to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by S. G. Landes is addressed to Robert E. Lee. He asks Lee to sign an autograph on a blank page included with this letter. He writes this letter from Mt. Carmel, Illinois although he notes that he grew up in the Rockbridge and Augusta counties of Virginia.

did.unittitle: Strobridge & Co. to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by the Strobridge Lithography Company is addressed to Robert E. Lee. The letter references lithographs of Robert E. Lee. The company apologizes for a delay in delivery of one example explaining that fire had destroyed its Cincinnati studio, including that Lee lithograph portrait. They share that a third lithograph is in process as well as a portrait of Stonewall Jackson.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
F. Bullwinkle to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by F. Bullwinkle is for Robert E. Lee. Bullwinkle wishes to get a mathematical education from Washington College and would like a catalogue.

did.unittitle: Stonewall Literary Society to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by members of the Stonewall Literary Society is for Robert E. Lee. The society writes to Lee that they have decided to make him an honorary member for his actions at the Siege of Petersburg, Virginia during the American Civil War.

did.unittitle: Richard Pennefather Rothwell

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Richard Pennefather Rothwell is to Robert E. Lee. Rothwell has heard that Washington College is increasing its staff and offers his services as a professor. He offers to be a professor of mining, metallurgy, mineralogy, or geology.

controlaccess.subject: Mining schools and education
Geology
Mining engineering
Mineralogy
Metallurgy
controlaccess.corpname: École nationale supérieure des mines de Paris

did.unittitle: Robert V. Richardson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Robert Vinkler Richardson is for Robert E. Lee. Richardson is trying to establish foreign investment in the southern American cotton industry. This letter is written on a circular sent out to different cotton planters, with this one having a hand-written letter for Lee.

controlaccess.subject: Cotton
Investments, Foreign
controlaccess.corpname: Messers. Bellot des Miniers, Bros. & Co.
Confederate States of America. Army. Cavalry

did.unittitle: Thomas Roberts Slicer to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Thomas Roberts Slicer is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Slicer, the son of Lee's friend Henry Slicer, inquires about a position to teach elocution at Washington College.

did.unittitle: Daniel F. Wright to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Daniel F. Wright is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Wright asks for a circular of Washington College to give a potential student he knows. He also mentions that he was a surgeon in Archer's Brigade during the American Civil War.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army. Tennessee Brigade

did.unittitle: James Cleland to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by James Cleland is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Cleland, a plumber and gas-fitter in Lynchburg, offers his services to Washington College to install a gas system. Included with this letter is a pamphlet from the Automatic Gas Company of Baltimore advertising their product.

did.unittitle: J. C. Parks to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by J. C. Parks is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Parks asks Lee if he and "Mr. Frazier" may be the publishers of Lee's American Civil War history in the southern states. Their conditions are that they would liberally compensate Lee and that half of the profits be given to widows and orphans of fallen Confederate soldiers. They list Casper Bell, John Bullock Clark, and John Heagan as references.

did.unittitle: Warren S. Barlow to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Warren S. Barlow is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Barlow writes that Lee's portrait by Elijah C. Middleton has been finished. He will send it by express to "Mr. Lutz" for Lee to receive.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Simon Bolivar Buckner to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Simon Bolivar Buckner is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Buckner introduces a student of Washington College he knows, J. Esten Cooke. Buckner also tells Lee that he is currently in New Orleans working as an editor for a paper.

did.unittitle: Charles B. Richardson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Charles B. Richardson is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Enclosed with this letter was a map of the Potomac Army that Lee requested, as well as John Beauchamp Jones' "A Rebel War Clerk's Diary" for ideas. Along with this package, Richardson updates Lee on the publishing of Henry Lee III's memoirs. Richardson also tells Lee that he is going through some financial setbacks but that it shouldn't hinder his business.

controlaccess.subject: Publishing
Map publishing
controlaccess.corpname: United States. Army of the Potomac

did.unittitle: Ancrum B. Burr to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Ancrum B. Burr is addressed to Robert E. Lee. She wishes for her son, Edward Johnston, to attend Washington College and would like a circular. Burr also says that Edward's father may have graduated from the United States Military Academy around the same time as Lee, but that he died in the Mexican-American War.

did.unittitle: John Mimms and Edwin O'Brien to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by John Mimms and Edwin O'Brien is addressed to Robert E. Lee. They say that several students in their town wish to attend Washington College and would like a catalogue.

did.unittitle: Richmond Light Infantry Blues to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by members of the Richmond Light Infantry Blues is addressed to Robert E. Lee. The militia group is celebrating its seventy-third anniversary on May 10, 1866 and is inviting Lee to celebrate.

controlaccess.corpname: Virginia. Militia. Richmond Light Infantry Blues

did.unittitle: Houston Rucker to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Houston Rucker is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Rucker writes that he would like a circular and information on Washington College to send a friend's son.

did.unittitle: Seaton Gales to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Seaton Gales is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Gales, an editor of the Raleigh Sentinel (N.C.) newspaper, offers to help identify a publisher for Lee's proposed book on the American Civil War. Gales included a copy of the Raleigh Sentinel with the letter. At the end of the letter Gales notes that he was an Assistant Adjutant General under General Stephen Dodson Ramseur

did.unittitle: George Dawes Appleton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by George Dawes Appleton is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Dawes writes that he wants to admit his son to Washington College and would like information about attending.

did.unittitle: John T. Adkisson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Adkisson, who had attended Dolbear Commercial College in New Orleans, La., inquires about continuing his education at Washington College and offers a plan for how he may be able to afford it. He notes that he served in a Texas Brigade during the American Civil War.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army. Texas Brigade

did.unittitle: James F. Dumble to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by James F. Dumble is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Dumble wants to send his son, around fifteen years of age, to Washington College and would like to know the terms of entering. He also asks if his son can board with a family.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Reverend William Norvell Ward to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Reverend William Norvell Ward is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Ward wants to know if Lee would like a photographic copy of a painting by Mattie Ward, his daughter. The subject of this painting is Stratford Hall, Lee's birthplace.

did.unittitle: J. F. Heun to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by J. F. Heun is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Heun asks Lee for an autographed wartime document.

did.unittitle: W. H. Nettleton to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by W. H. Nettleton is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Nettleton, an Englishman having traveled the county over the past year, writes that he would like a hand-written line or two from Lee as a souvenir of this trip.

did.unittitle: Josiah Warren to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Josiah Warren is addressed to Robert E. Lee. This letter accompanied a book Warren wanted Lee to read.

did.unittitle: Horatio Richardson Moore to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Horatio Richardson Moore is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Moore asks if it would be okay for some acquaintances in New Orleans to use Lee's name in their company.

did.unittitle: William T. Somervell to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by William T. Somervell is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Somervell wishes to attend Washington College and asks for a circular, terms, and regulations for applying.

did.unittitle: Mansfield Lovell to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Mansfield Lovell is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Having heard that Lee is writing a history of the American Civil War, Lovell offers a list of documents from Confederate officers in his possession for Lee to borrow from. Mansfield notes his documents of evidence taken by the Joint Congressional Committee on the affairs of the Confederate Naval Department, and correspondence between the Confederate States of America War Department and General Lafayette McLaws concerning the fate of New Orleans, Louisiana.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. War Department

did.unittitle: Robert Lewis Dabney to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Robert Lewis Dabney is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Dabney writes that an advertisement of his Stonewall Jackson biography gives credit of Lee's review and revisions to the publisher instead. He explains to Lee that the publisher decided to do this, not him.

did.unittitle: Lizzie C. Hull to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Lizzie C. Hull is addressed to Robert E. Lee. She acknowledges the receipt that her son cannot attend Washington College and wishes the best for Lee.

did.unittitle: Jeannette Ritchie Hadermann Walworth to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Jeannette Ritchie Hadermann Walworth is addressed to Robert E. Lee. She asks for a piece of Lee's hair for her nephew who is also named Lee in honor of him.

did.unittitle: Correspondences
Jubal Anderson Early to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Jubal Early recounts his participation in battles of the American Civil War and describes his experience living in Mexico since the Confederate surrender and his planned move to Canada.
The original envelope is included with this letter.

controlaccess.corpname: Confederate States of America. Army of Northern Virginia. Early's Division
Confederate States of America. Army of Northern Virginia. Corps, 3rd
Confederate States of America. Army of Northern Virginia. Corps, 2nd

did.unittitle: Aaron Howell Pierson Sr. to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Aaron Howell Pierson Sr. is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Pierson wishes to send his son to Washington College but does not know the requirements. Pierson worries that because of his son's service in the American Civil War, he may be too far behind his studies to attend.

did.unittitle: James Dabney McCabe to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by James Dabney McCabe is addressed to Robert E. Lee. McCabe asks if he can write a narration of Lee's actions during the American Civil War. He notes that as an ex-cadet of Virginia Military Institue, he published "A Life of Lieut. Gen. T. J. Jackson" during the war.

did.unittitle: R. Thompson to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by R. Thompson is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Thompson offers to publish a British edition of Lee's planned book on the American Civil War. Lee never wrote the book.

did.unittitle: Sam Beach Jones to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by the Reverend Samuel Beach Jones is addressed to Robert E. Lee, updating him on events. Jones has found the whereabouts of a painting taken from Lee's Arlington house. Jones also found another painting of a winter scene but doesn't know for sure that it belonged to Lee. Along with these paintings, Jones has come across a book that supposedly comes from Lee's library but is marked as belonging to Charles A. Atkinson. Along with these matters, Jones says that he is taking a trip to Europe and offers to collect money for Washington College.

controlaccess.geogname: Arlington House, the Robert E. Lee Memorial (Va.)

did.unittitle: John Speck LeFevre to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by John Speck LaFever is addressed to Robert E. Lee. LaFever asks for information to attend Washington College.

did.unittitle: Dr. Wesley Emmett Gatwood to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Dr. Wesley Emmett Gatewood is addressed to Robert E. Lee. Gatewood would like information on attending Washington College and a piece of clothing Lee wore during the American Civil War.

did.unittitle: Augustus Machim Garber to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by Augustus Machim Garber is addressed to Robert E. Lee. He writes that he has sent catalogues of Washington College to his uncle. However, his uncle would like information on fees and payment to the school. Garber also mentions sculptor William Rudolph O'Donovan and shares that the scultpor, with approval from Lee, will continue workingon a bust of Stonwall Jackson.
Originally included with this letter was a photograph of O'Donovan's bust of Stonewall Jackson.

Busts
Statues

did.unittitle: C. Williams to Robert E. Lee

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This letter by C. Williams is addressed to Robert E. Lee on behalf of the Great Southern and Western Life and Accident Insurance Company announcing a forthcoming shareholders meeting.

controlaccess.subject: Insurance
Fire insurance
